awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Improving the Implementation of Rigorous Instructional Materials in Middle-Grades Mathematics: Developing a System of Practical Measures and Routines
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this 5-year research project is to improve the implementation of rigorous instructional materials in middle-grades mathematics at scale. Many projects seek to improve mathematics instruction, but are not able to easily track their efforts at improvement. The primary product of this project will be a system of practical measures and routines for collecting and using data that both assesses and supports the implementation of rigorous instructional materials in middle-grades mathematics. In contrast to research and accountability measures, practical measures are assessments that require little time to administer and can thus be used frequently. The data can be analyzed rapidly so that teachers can receive prompt feedback on their progress, and instructional leaders can use the data to decide where to target resources to support improvement in the quality of instruction and student learning. The system of practical measures and routines will include 1) measures of high-leverage aspects of teachers' instructional practices that have been linked to student learning (e.g., rigor of tasks, quality of students' discourse) and attend to equitable student participation; and 2) measures of high-leverage aspects of key supports for improving the quality of teachers' practice (e.g., quality of professional development; coaching); and 3) a set of routines regarding how to use the resulting data to engage in rapid, improvement efforts. A key principle of the proposed project is that the system of measures and routines can be adapted to a wide range of school and district contexts. This project is supported by the Discovery Research preK-12 (DRK-12) program. The DRK-12 program supports research and development of STEM education innovations and approaches in assessment, learning, and teaching. 

The project will establish three research-practice partnerships with five districts, in three different states, that are currently implementing rigorous instructional materials in middle-grades mathematics. Year 1 will focus on the development of a set of practical measures of classroom instruction. Year 2 will focus on testing the use of the classroom measures in the context of supports for teachers' learning, and the development of practical measures of key supports for teachers' learning. Years 3-4 will focus on how the project can "learn our way to scale" (Bryk et al., 2015), which requires strategically implementing measures and routines in increasingly diverse conditions. The project will engage in rapid improvement cycles in which researchers will work alongside district leaders and professional development (PD) facilitators to analyze the data from the measures of both classroom instruction and the quality of support for teacher learning to test the effectiveness of improvements in intended supports for teacher learning and to adjust the design of the support based on data. Across Years 1-4, the project will use recent developments in technology and information visualization to test and improve 1) the collection of practical measures in situ and 2) the design of data representations (or visualizations) that support teachers and leaders to make instructional improvement decisions. In Year 5, the project will conduct formal analyses of the relations between supports for teachers' learning; teachers' knowledge and classroom practices; and student learning.

por.por_cntn:
The project was conducted in close collaboration with the mathematics leaders of a large urban district. The common problem that we addressed was to support a cadre of mathematics coaches in conducting coaching cycles effectively with individual teachers, where a cycle consists of three phases:

  • A lesson planning phase in which the coach and teacher plan a lesson together
  • A classroom phase in which the teacher teaches the lesson and the coach observes, the teacher and coach co-teach the lesson, or the coach teaches the lesson and the teacher observes
  • A debriefing phase in which the coach and teacher analyze students’ learning and instruction in the lesson

We focused on coaching cycles because prior research indicates that they can have a positive impact on teachers’ instruction and students’ mathematical learning. In addition to having a strong pragmatic emphasis, this work makes two significant contributions to research coaching and teacher development.

 

First, we and our district colleagues determined how coaches can 1) identify what we term productive improvement goals that are specific to individual teachers’ needs, and then 2) negotiate productive goals with teachers so that they see them as worth pursuing. Productive improvement goals are:

  • Feasible for teachers to attain given their current knowledge and practice.
  • Likely to result in immediate improvements in students’ learning if they are attained.

It is essential that coaches identify productive goals that are specific to individual teachers’ needs if their work is to pay off in terms of improved student learning. It is also important that teachers’ come to see productive goals as worthwhile if they are to invest the sustained effort necessary to attain them. We and our district colleagues investigated what it might take to support coaches in learning to identify and negotiate productive goals by designing and then analyzing coaches’ learning in a sequence of professional development sessions. Our findings indicate these are feasible learning goals for coaches and that a relatively modest amount of professional development can be sufficient.

 

Second, as part of this work, we collaborated with colleagues at several other universities to develop a set of three practical measures of the quality of classroom mathematics instruction.  In contrast to other types of measures including accountability measures, practical measures are designed to provide educators (e.g., teachers, coaches, district leaders) with rapid feedback that can inform their ongoing improvement efforts.  The measures that we developed assess the quality of:

  • The introduction or launch of challenging, non-routine mathematical tasks
  • Students’ small group work
  • Concluding whole class discussion of students’ solutions

Each measure is a short student surveys that can be completed in three minutes or less, thus minimizing disruptions to teaching. The items on each survey assess aspects of the classroom learning environment that prior research has linked to students’ learning.  As part of the professional development mentioned above, we supported coaches in integrating the practical measures into coaching cycles:

  • Lesson planning phase: select the specific measure that is aligned with the improvement goal that their partner teacher is working on
  • Classroom phase: administer the student survey at the end of the lesson
  • Debriefing phase: analyze students’ responses (aggregated at the classroom level) together with other types of data (e.g., students’ work).

 

We investigated whether this use of the practical measures can enhance coaches’ effectiveness in supporting teachers’ learning and found three benefits.  First, consistent with prior work on practical measurement, we found that use of the measures enabled coaches and teachers to determine whether an instructional change they had made improved students’ learning opportunities. Second, use of the measures can enable coaches and teachers to develop more powerful explanations of how instruction influenced students’ learning than would otherwise be the case. This is because many of the survey items focus on aspects of the classroom learning environment that matter for students’ learning but that are not directly observable and thus might well have gone unnoticed. Third, use of the practical measures can enable coaches and teachers to resolve disagreements that arise when analyzing lessons because students’ survey responses provide a third, independent perspective on the lesson. In other words, use of the practical measures was advantageous because it brought the students’ voice to the fore.

 

It is important to clarify that practical measures are not silver bullets. The extent to which use of the measures enhances coaches’ effectiveness beyond determining whether a change is an improvement depends on how they facilitate teachers’ analysis of practical measures data. It is essential that coaches press their partner teachers to relate students’ survey responses to instruction in the lesson. In doing so, coaches support teachers in considering how the instruction shaped the classroom learning environment as experience by students. It is only then that coaches unlock the full potential of the practical measures.
